title: Lord Wolfson of Next plc calls for investment to boost UK economy | Leicester Mercury
text:
Two major manufacturers from Leicestershire have warned prices or their products could go the way of Marmite. 
Brand owner Unilever mad headlines this week when it said an increase in costs meant it had to put up prices – sparking a brief stand-off with Tesco. 
For companies importing food, prices will likely rise because a fall in the value of sterling means the pound buys less abroad. 
As a result, suppliers may have to put up their prices to protect their profits. 
Next chief executive Lord Wolfson, meanwhile, warned in an interview with the BBC that retailers are facing higher inflation and because of this prices are likely to rise. 
A supporter of Brexit, he said the answer is to boost the economy in other ways – such as trade deals with countries outside the European Union and investing in infrastructure. 
Increasing the wealth of the economy will mitigate any increase in inflation, he argued, as consumers become richer and so price rises become easier to handle. 
Lord Wolfson said: "I think inevitably the decline in the pound will mean there will be some inflation coming into the United Kingdom. 
"That will present an additional challenge to us next year and probably the year after. 
"But the key thing is that we come up with ways of stimulating our economy to counter that effect, to mitigate it. 
"One of the ways we can do that is through investment in the right infrastructure." 
Deputy Bank of England governor Minouche Shafiq expects the cost of living to rise – read the full story in Business, in Monday's Leicester Mercury.
